misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays lose alignment when sorting only one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array automatically keeps the corresponding names matched to their scores, so they can take the last score and the last name as the top student.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(studentScores)` reorders only the `studentScores` array. It does not (and cannot) automatically reorder `studentNames` to maintain name–score pairing. Parallel arrays require you to swap elements in *both* arrays whenever you reorder by one key, or to sort indices/objects that preserve the association.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (often prints the wrong name for the highest score). The score printed will be the maximum, but the name is just whatever was originally in the last position of the input.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort the studentScores array using Arrays.sort(), the studentNames array will automatically remain synchronized with it. They think that sorting one array will preserve the original index relationships between the two arrays, so the student name at index (numberOfStudents - 1) will still correspond to the highest score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that Arrays.sort() only sorts the specified array in place and does not affect other arrays. Parallel arrays require manual synchronization during sorting—when you swap elements in one array, you must swap the corresponding elements in the other array. By sorting only the scores array, the names and scores become misaligned. The highest score will be at the last index of studentScores, but the corresponding name at the last index of studentNames will be whatever was originally there, not the name of the student who actually achieved that highest score.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program will print the name of the last student (in input order) rather than the name of the student with the highest score. For the sample input, it will output 'Charlie (92)' instead of 'Bob (92)'.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array in a set of parallel arrays automatically preserves the relationship with other arrays, or that the indices in the names array will implicitly update to match the new order of the scores array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Java execution model treats arrays as independent objects. Calling `Arrays.sort()` on the `studentScores` array reorders its elements in memory but has no effect on the `studentNames` array. Because the link between the two arrays is only maintained by the programmer's use of matching indices, sorting one array independently breaks the parallel relationship, causing the names and scores to become desynchronized.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay synchronized after sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array will still keep each score matched with the corresponding name at the same index in the `names` array, so they can safely take the last index from both arrays to get the top student.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(studentScores)` reorders only the `studentScores` array. The `studentNames` array is unchanged, so the index-based pairing between name and score is broken. With parallel arrays, any swap/reorder must be applied to *both* arrays in tandem (or the data should be stored together in an object and sorted as a unit).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Incorrect output (prints the wrong student name for the highest score). For the sample input, it would print `Top student: Charlie (92)` instead of `Bob (92)`.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array will maintain the correspondence between the names and scores at the same indices. They think that after sorting scores, accessing studentNames[numberOfStudents - 1] will correctly retrieve the name of the student whose score is at studentScores[numberOfStudents - 1].
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that parallel arrays maintain their correspondence through index alignment. When one array is sorted independently, the index-based relationship with the other array is broken. Sorting studentScores rearranges only the scores, leaving the names array in its original order. This breaks the one-to-one mapping between indices. To maintain parallel array relationships, both arrays must be sorted together using the same swap operations, or a custom sorting mechanism must track indices.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program will output the correct highest score but pair it with the wrong student name. For the sample input (Alice 85, Bob 92, Charlie 78), the output will be 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)'.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the 'studentNames' and 'studentScores' arrays were populated together to represent the same entities, an operation that reorders one array (like Arrays.sort) will automatically reorder the other to maintain the established data pairs.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, parallel arrays are entirely independent objects in memory. The relationship between elements is maintained solely by the programmer using identical indices; the JVM and standard library methods like Arrays.sort() have no awareness of these relationships. Sorting one array decouples it from the other.
